practices.description: Limit information system access to authorized users, processes acting on behalf of authorized users, or devices (including other information systems).
evidence_artifacts: System Security Plan (SSP) Access Control section
List of active accounts (User, Service, Admin)
Active Directory Group Policy Objects (GPOs) for account settings
practices.implementation_tips: Avoid assigning permissions to individual users. Use Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) groups (e.g., 'Engineering-Read', 'HR-Write'). Automate account disabling based on HR termination dates.

practices.description: Limit information system access to the types of transactions and functions that authorized users are permitted to execute.
evidence_artifacts: RBAC Matrix or Access Control Matrix
Screenshots of permissions for key roles
practices.implementation_tips: Map job titles to specific IT roles. Ensure a 'Software Engineer' cannot access 'HR Payroll' folders. Use 'Least Privilege' as your guiding principle.

practices.description: Control the flow of CUI in accordance with approved authorizations.
practices.implementation_tips: Identify where CUI lives. Configure firewalls and VLANs to stop CUI from moving to unapproved networks (e.g., Guest WiFi or Test environments).

practices.description: Separate the duties of individuals to reduce the risk of malevolent activity without collusion.
evidence_artifacts: List of users with multiple conflicting roles (e.g., Developer + Production Admin)
Access logs showing distinct users performing conflicting tasks
practices.implementation_tips: Ensure the person who *writes* the code is not the same person who *pushes* it to production. Ensure the person who *approves* a check is not the one who *cuts* it.

practices.description: Employ the principle of least privilege, including for specific security functions and privileged accounts.
evidence_artifacts: Audit trails of privileged command usage
GPO settings restricting 'Debug programs' and other rights
practices.implementation_tips: Admins should have two accounts: a daily user account (jsmith) and an admin account (adm-jsmith). They should only use the admin account when necessary.

practices.description: Use non-privileged accounts or roles when accessing nonsecurity functions.
evidence_artifacts: Policy stating admins must use standard accounts for email/web browsing
Audit logs showing admin accounts are not used for non-admin tasks
practices.implementation_tips: Technical enforcement is hard. Rely on policy and training: 'Don't read email as root/Administrator'.

practices.description: Prevent non-privileged users from executing privileged functions and capture the execution of such functions in audit logs.
evidence_artifacts: Audit logs showing 'Run as Administrator' events
Screenshots of blocked installations for standard users
practices.implementation_tips: Remove local admin rights from all standard user workstations. This is the single most effective security control you can implement.

practices.description: Limit unsuccessful logon attempts.
evidence_artifacts: Screenshots of lockout configuration (e.g., 3 attempts, 30 min lockout)
practices.implementation_tips: Standard is usually 3-5 failed attempts triggers a 15-30 minute lockout. Be careful with service accounts; if they lock out, applications crash.

practices.description: Provide privacy and security notices consistent with applicable CUI rules.
evidence_artifacts: Screenshot of the 'Logon Banner' on workstations and servers
Text of the banner matching DoD requirements
practices.implementation_tips: Configure the 'Interactive logon: Message text for users attempting to log on' GPO. Ensure it explicitly mentions US Government monitoring and consent.

practices.description: Use session lock with pattern-hiding displays to prevent access and viewing of data after a period of inactivity.
evidence_artifacts: Screensaver GPO settings (15 mins or less)
Screenshot showing 'On resume, display logon screen' checked
practices.implementation_tips: Set the inactivity timer to 15 minutes. Ensure the screensaver is a blank screen or company logo, not personal photos.

practices.description: Terminate (automatically) a user session after a defined condition.
practices.implementation_tips: This applies mostly to remote access (VPN) and high-value web apps. A 12-hour VPN disconnect is common to force daily re-authentication.

practices.description: Monitor and control remote access sessions.
evidence_artifacts: Firewall logs showing blocked remote connections
practices.implementation_tips: Centralize all remote access through a single VPN concentrator. Do not allow direct RDP/SSH from the internet.

practices.description: Employ cryptographic mechanisms to protect the confidentiality of remote access sessions.
evidence_artifacts: FIPS 140-2 validation certificates for VPN modules
Configuration showing TLS 1.2 or higher only
SSH configuration disabling weak ciphers (e.g., DES, MD5)
practices.implementation_tips: Ensure your VPN and SSH servers are configured to reject old protocols (SSLv3, TLS 1.0, TLS 1.1).

practices.description: Route remote access via managed access control points.
evidence_artifacts: Network Diagram showing VPN entry point
Firewall rules blocking direct external access to internal IPs
practices.implementation_tips: Force all traffic through your DMZ/Firewall. No 'split tunneling' for accessing internal resources directly.

practices.description: Authorize remote execution of privileged commands and remote access to security-relevant information.
evidence_artifacts: Policy explicitly authorizing remote admin work
Access Control Lists (ACLs) for remote management interfaces
practices.implementation_tips: Create a 'Jump Box' or 'Bastion Host'. Admins RDP/SSH into the Jump Box first, *then* manage servers from there.

practices.description: Authorize wireless access prior to allowing such connections.
evidence_artifacts: List of authorized wireless devices (MAC filtering or 802.1x logs)
practices.implementation_tips: Do not allow personal devices on the corporate secure Wi-Fi. Use 802.1x authentication (Certificate-based) if possible.

practices.description: Protect wireless access using authentication and encryption.
evidence_artifacts: WAP Configuration showing WPA2-Enterprise or WPA3
practices.implementation_tips: WEP and WPA (original) are forbidden. Use WPA2-AES or WPA3. Shared keys (PSK) are discouraged for enterprise networks; use individual credentials.

practices.description: Control connection of mobile devices.
practices.implementation_tips: If mobile devices access CUI (email), they MUST be managed. If they are BYOD, use a 'Containerized' app approach (MAM).

practices.description: Encrypt CUI on mobile devices and mobile computing platforms.
evidence_artifacts: MDM settings enforcing Full Disk Encryption (BitLocker/FileVault)
Screenshots of encrypted storage on phones/tablets
practices.implementation_tips: Enforce encryption *before* email profiles are installed. iOS and Android encrypt by default now, but you need to prove it via policy check.

practices.description: Verify and control/limit connections to and use of external information systems.
practices.implementation_tips: Document any connection to a partner, vendor, or cloud service. Treat them as 'External' and filter traffic aggressively.

practices.description: Limit use of portable storage devices on external systems.
evidence_artifacts: Technical controls (DLP/GPO) blocking USB write access on external endpoints
User training records regarding USB risks
practices.implementation_tips: Simplest way: Ban USB storage entirely. If you must use it, issue company-owned, encrypted drives only.

practices.description: Control CUI posted or processed on publicly accessible systems.
evidence_artifacts: Logs of content approval (Marketing/Public Affairs reviews)
practices.implementation_tips: Ensure no technical diagrams, internal rosters, or meeting minutes are posted to the public company website.

practices.description: Ensure that managers, systems administrators, and users of organizational systems are made aware of the security risks associated with their activities...
evidence_artifacts: Attendance records / Learning Management System (LMS) reports
practices.implementation_tips: Use a platform like KnowBe4 or Proofpoint. Automate the reminders. Training must happen *before* access is granted.

practices.description: Ensure that personnel are trained to carry out their assigned information security-related duties and responsibilities.
evidence_artifacts: Role-Based Training records (e.g., for Admins, Developers)
Certifications held by IT staff (Security+, CISSP)
practices.implementation_tips: Admins need more than generic phishing training. They need secure system administration training (e.g., Linux Hardening, Windows Security).

practices.description: Provide security awareness training on recognizing and reporting potential indicators of insider threat.
evidence_artifacts: Completion records for Insider Threat training
practices.implementation_tips: Train users to spot disgruntled colleagues, unauthorized data hoarding, or unusual working hours. Make reporting anonymous.

practices.description: Create and retain system audit logs and records to the extent needed to enable the monitoring, analysis, investigation, and reporting of unlawful or unauthorized system activity.
evidence_artifacts: Audit Policy configuration (Windows Audit Policy / Linux audit.rules)
Log retention policy (e.g., 90 days online, 1 year archive)
practices.implementation_tips: Enable 'Process Creation' logging with command line arguments. This is invaluable for forensics. Ensure you have enough disk space.

practices.description: Ensure that the actions of individual system users can be uniquely traced to those users so they can be held accountable for their actions.
evidence_artifacts: List of any shared accounts with justification and compensating controls
Log samples showing 'Username' field is populated
practices.implementation_tips: Eliminate 'admin', 'root', 'guest', or 'student' generic logins. Every human needs a named account.

practices.description: Review and update logged events.
evidence_artifacts: Evidence of weekly/daily reviews (tickets, sign-offs, SIEM alerts)
Feedback loop showing policy updates based on findings
practices.implementation_tips: Humans cannot manually review raw logs. Use a tool (SIEM) to generate alerts/reports, and review the *reports*.

practices.description: Alert in the event of an audit logging process failure.
evidence_artifacts: Configuration of alerts for 'Log Service Stopped' or 'Disk Full'
System configuration to 'Shut down on audit failure' (extreme, but compliant)
practices.implementation_tips: Set up an alert if free disk space on the log server drops below 20%.

practices.description: Correlate audit record review, analysis, and reporting processes for investigation and response to indications of unlawful, unauthorized, suspicious, or unusual activity.
evidence_artifacts: Incident Response Plan referencing log analysis
Examples of correlated alerts (e.g., 'Multiple failed logins' + 'Successful login')
practices.implementation_tips: You need a central log aggregator (Splunk, ELK, Graylog, Azure Sentinel) to correlate events across different servers.

practices.description: Provide audit record reduction and report generation to support on-demand analysis and reporting.
evidence_artifacts: Sample reports (e.g., 'All logins by User X in last 30 days')
practices.implementation_tips: Ensure you can quickly answer: 'Show me everything IP address X did yesterday'.

practices.description: Provide a system capability that compares and synchronizes internal system clocks with an authoritative source to generate time stamps for audit records.
evidence_artifacts: Firewall rules allowing NTP traffic to US Naval Observatory or NIST time servers
practices.implementation_tips: Point your Domain Controller (PDC Emulator) to an external stratum 1 source (e.g., `time.nist.gov`). Point all other servers to the DC.

practices.description: Protect audit information and audit logging tools from unauthorized access, modification, and deletion.
evidence_artifacts: ACLs on log folders (Read-only for most, No Delete)
File Integrity Monitoring (FIM) on log files
Separate admin account for Audit management
practices.implementation_tips: Send logs off-box immediately. If an attacker hacks a server, they will wipe the local logs. They shouldn't be able to wipe the remote log server.

practices.description: Limit management of audit logging functionality to a subset of privileged users.
evidence_artifacts: List of users with 'Manage Auditing and Security Log' right
RBAC definitions separating 'System Admin' from 'Audit Admin'
practices.implementation_tips: Only specific security personnel should be able to turn off logging or clear the logs.

practices.description: Establish and maintain baseline configurations and inventories of organizational systems...
practices.implementation_tips: Use automated tools for inventory (Lansweeper, PDQ Inventory). Manual spreadsheets are always out of date.

practices.description: Establish and enforce security configuration settings for information technology products employed in organizational systems.
practices.implementation_tips: Apply DISA STIGs or CIS Benchmarks. Don't guess. Use Group Policy or Ansible to enforce them.

practices.description: Track, review, approve or disapprove, and log changes to organizational systems.
evidence_artifacts: Log of approved vs. implemented changes
practices.implementation_tips: You don't need a heavy process for everything, but major changes (firewall rules, new software) need a paper trail of approval.

practices.description: Analyze the security impact of changes prior to implementation.
evidence_artifacts: Security Impact Analysis (SIA) section on Change Forms
practices.implementation_tips: Ask: 'Does this change open a new port? Does it require a new admin account?' If yes, flag for security review.

practices.description: Define, document, approve, and enforce physical and logical access restrictions associated with changes to organizational systems.
evidence_artifacts: Access lists for who can push code/config changes
Physical access logs to server rooms during maintenance windows
practices.implementation_tips: Only authorized admins should be able to alter the configuration. Developers should not have write access to Production.

practices.description: Employ the principle of least functionality by configuring organizational systems to provide only essential capabilities.
evidence_artifacts: Baseline configuration showing removal of games/bloatware
practices.implementation_tips: Uninstall unused IIS, Telnet, FTP, and Xbox services on Windows Servers.

practices.description: Restrict, disable, or prevent the use of nonessential programs, functions, ports, protocols, and services.
practices.implementation_tips: Block standard users from running .exe files from their Downloads folder. Use AppLocker or WDAC.

practices.description: Apply deny-by-exception (blacklisting) policy to prevent the use of unauthorized software or deny-all, permit-by-exception (whitelisting) policy...
evidence_artifacts: Enterprise Antivirus blocking P2P/File Sharing apps
practices.implementation_tips: Whitelisting is harder but much more secure. Start by blacklisting known bads (Tor, BitTorrent, Games).

practices.description: Control and monitor user-installed software.
practices.implementation_tips: If users don't have Local Admin rights, they can't install most software. This solves 90% of this control.

practices.description: Identify system users, processes acting on behalf of users, and devices.
practices.implementation_tips: Ensure every human has a unique ID. No sharing 'Admin' or 'FrontDesk' accounts.

practices.description: Authenticate (or verify) the identities of users, processes, or devices, as a prerequisite to allowing access to organizational systems.
practices.implementation_tips: This is the basic 'Username + Password' requirement. Ensure empty passwords are disabled.

practices.description: Use multifactor authentication for local and network access to privileged accounts and for network access to non-privileged accounts.
evidence_artifacts: Test results showing prompt on RDP/VPN
practices.implementation_tips: MFA is required for: 1. All remote access (VPN). 2. All Privileged access (Local or Remote). 3. Access to CUI data.

practices.description: Employ replay-resistant authentication mechanisms for network access to privileged and non-privileged accounts.
practices.implementation_tips: Kerberos is replay-resistant. NTLM is vulnerable. Enforce Kerberos in your Windows domain.

practices.description: Prevent reuse of identifiers for a defined period.
evidence_artifacts: AD settings prohibiting deleting and re-creating same username immediately
practices.implementation_tips: If 'John Doe' (jdoe) leaves, and a new 'Jane Doe' (jdoe) starts, do not reuse the username. Use 'jdoe2' or similar.

practices.description: Disable identifiers after a defined period of inactivity.
evidence_artifacts: GPO or AD Attribute checking LastLogonTimeStamp
practices.implementation_tips: Script this. 'If LastLogon > 45 days, Disable Account'.

practices.description: Enforce a minimum password complexity and change of characters when new passwords are created.
practices.implementation_tips: 12+ characters, upper, lower, number, special. Or better yet, 15+ characters passphrase.

practices.description: Prohibit password reuse for a specified number of generations.
evidence_artifacts: Password History setting in GPO (e.g., Remember last 24 passwords)
practices.implementation_tips: Standard is usually 24 generations.

practices.description: Allow temporary password use for system logons with an immediate change to a permanent password.
evidence_artifacts: AD setting 'User must change password at next logon'
practices.implementation_tips: When resetting a user's password, ALWAYS check 'User must change password at next logon'.

practices.description: Store and transmit only cryptographically-protected passwords.
practices.implementation_tips: Ensure 'Store passwords using reversible encryption' is DISABLED in GPO.

practices.description: Obscure feedback of authentication information.
evidence_artifacts: Screenshot of login screen showing asterisks/bullets for password field
practices.implementation_tips: This is default behavior in almost all modern OSs. Just verify no 'Show Password' button is enabled by default.

practices.description: Establish an operational incident-handling capability...
practices.implementation_tips: You don't need a SOC, but you need a defined person who is 'in charge' when a hack happens.

practices.description: Track, document, and report incidents to designated officials...
evidence_artifacts: Incident Tracking Log (spreadsheet or ticket system)
practices.implementation_tips: Know your reporting timeline (72 hours for DoD). Have the DIBNet URL bookmarked.

practices.description: Test the organizational incident response capability.
practices.implementation_tips: Do an annual tabletop exercise. Scenario: 'Ransomware hit the HR server. What do we do?' Document the discussion.

practices.description: Perform maintenance on organizational systems.
practices.implementation_tips: Patching counts as maintenance. Keeping hardware under warranty counts.

practices.description: Provide controls on the tools, techniques, mechanisms, and personnel used to conduct system maintenance.
evidence_artifacts: List of approved maintenance tools (e.g., diagnostic software)
Vetting process for external maintenance personnel
practices.implementation_tips: Don't let vendors plug in their own USB sticks. Scan their tools first.

practices.description: Ensure equipment removed for off-site maintenance is sanitized of any CUI.
evidence_artifacts: Policy requiring hard drive removal before repair
practices.implementation_tips: If a laptop goes to Dell for repair, KEEP the hard drive. Do not send the drive.

practices.description: Check media containing diagnostic and test programs for malicious code before the media are used in organizational systems.
evidence_artifacts: Logs of AV scans on external media
practices.implementation_tips: Scan the CD/USB on a standalone non-networked machine first.

practices.description: Require multifactor authentication to establish nonlocal maintenance sessions via external network connections and terminate such connections when nonlocal maintenance is complete.
evidence_artifacts: MFA logs for vendor remote access
practices.implementation_tips: Vendors should use the same VPN+MFA path as employees. No TeamViewer/AnyDesk unless explicitly managed/logged.

practices.description: Supervise the maintenance activities of maintenance personnel without required access authorization.
practices.implementation_tips: If the HVAC guy is in the server room, an employee must be standing there watching them.

practices.description: Protect (i.e., physically control and securely store) system media containing CUI, both paper and digital.
evidence_artifacts: Access logs for secure storage areas
practices.implementation_tips: Lock up hard drives, flash drives, and printed documents when not in use.

practices.description: Limit access to CUI on system media to authorized users.
practices.implementation_tips: Not everyone needs keys to the CUI filing cabinet.

practices.description: Sanitize or destroy information system media containing CUI before disposal or release for reuse.
practices.implementation_tips: Use a cross-cut shredder for paper. Drill/Crush/De-magnetize hard drives.

practices.description: Mark media with necessary CUI markings and distribution limitations.
evidence_artifacts: Photos of marked USB drives / Hard Drives
practices.implementation_tips: Buy 'CUI' stickers. Stick them on every laptop and external drive that might hold data.

practices.description: Control access to media containing CUI and maintain accountability for media during transport outside of controlled areas.
practices.implementation_tips: If mailing CUI, use tracking and double wrapping.

practices.description: Implement cryptographic mechanisms to protect the confidentiality of CUI stored on digital media during transport unless otherwise protected by alternative physical safeguards.
evidence_artifacts: BitLocker To Go policies (Enforce encryption on removable drives)
practices.implementation_tips: Force encryption on all USBs. Or better, issue hardware-encrypted USB drives (FIPS 140-2 Level 3).

practices.description: Control the use of removable media on system components.
evidence_artifacts: GPO settings for Removable Storage Access
practices.implementation_tips: Disable USB Write access for standard users via GPO.

practices.description: Prohibit the use of portable storage devices when such devices have no identifiable owner.
practices.implementation_tips: The 'found USB in the parking lot' scenario. Train users never to plug these in.

practices.description: Protect the confidentiality of backup CUI at storage locations.
evidence_artifacts: Physical security of offsite backup location
practices.implementation_tips: Encrypt backups *before* they leave your network. Encrypt at rest in the cloud.

practices.description: Screen individuals prior to authorizing access to organizational systems containing CUI.
practices.implementation_tips: Standard background checks (criminal/employment) are usually sufficient unless ITAR/Classified requirements exist.

practices.description: Ensure that organizational systems containing CUI are protected during and after personnel actions such as terminations and transfers.
evidence_artifacts: Ticket showing account disablement timing vs termination timing
practices.implementation_tips: IT must be notified *before* the employee is fired. Disable access immediately upon termination.

practices.description: Limit physical access to organizational information systems, equipment, and the respective operating environments to authorized individuals.
practices.implementation_tips: Server rooms must be locked. Only IT should have keys/access.

practices.description: Protect and monitor the physical facility and support infrastructure for organizational systems.
practices.implementation_tips: Cameras at entry/exit points. Alarm system on the server room door.

practices.description: Escort visitors and monitor visitor activity.
practices.implementation_tips: Digital visitor logs are better (iPad kiosk). Ensure they record 'Time In' and 'Time Out'.

practices.description: Maintain audit logs of physical access.
practices.implementation_tips: Review physical access logs quarterly. Does the intern still have access to the server room?

practices.description: Control and manage physical access devices.
practices.implementation_tips: If a master key is lost, you must re-key the locks.

practices.description: Enforce safeguarding measures for CUI at alternate work sites.
practices.implementation_tips: Employees working from home must understand: 'Don't let family members use your work laptop'.

practices.description: Periodically assess the risk to organizational operations...
practices.implementation_tips: Perform a formal Risk Assessment annually or upon major change.

practices.description: Scan for vulnerabilities in organizational systems and applications periodically and when new vulnerabilities affecting those systems and applications are identified.
practices.implementation_tips: Scan weekly or monthly. You MUST use 'Credentialed Scans' to see missing patches inside the OS.

practices.description: Remediate vulnerabilities in accordance with risk assessments.
practices.implementation_tips: High/Critical vulnerabilities should be patched within days. Medium/Low can wait longer.

practices.description: Periodically assess the security controls in organizational systems to determine if the controls are effective in their application.
practices.implementation_tips: Do a self-assessment against 800-171 annually.

practices.description: Develop and implement plans of action designed to correct deficiencies and reduce or eliminate vulnerabilities in organizational systems.
evidence_artifacts: Plan of Action and Milestones (POA&M) document
practices.implementation_tips: The POA&M is a living document. If you can't fix it today, put it on the POA&M with a date.

practices.description: Monitor security controls on an ongoing basis to ensure the continued effectiveness of the controls.
practices.implementation_tips: Don't 'set and forget'. Check GPOs, Firewall rules, and AV status regularly.

practices.description: Develop, document, and periodically update system security plans that describe system boundaries...
practices.implementation_tips: The SSP is your master document. It describes *how* you meet every single one of these controls.

practices.description: Monitor, control, and protect organizational communications...
practices.implementation_tips: Define your boundary. The Firewall is the edge. Everything inside is the 'System'.

practices.description: Employ architectural designs, software development techniques, and systems engineering principles that promote effective information security...
practices.implementation_tips: Segregate networks (Servers, Workstations, IoT, Guest). Don't have a flat network.

practices.description: Separate user functionality from system management functionality.
practices.implementation_tips: Admins should manage servers from a dedicated Management VLAN or Jump Box, not their daily laptop.

practices.description: Prevent unauthorized and unintended information transfer via shared system resources.
practices.implementation_tips: Mostly handled by modern OSs and Hypervisors. Keep them patched.

practices.description: Implement subnetworks for publicly accessible system components that are physically or logically separated from internal networks.
evidence_artifacts: Firewall rules isolating DMZ from Internal LAN
practices.implementation_tips: Web servers accessible from the internet go in the DMZ. They should NOT talk to the internal DB directly if possible.

practices.description: Deny network communications traffic by default and allow network communications traffic by exception (i.e., deny all, permit by exception).
evidence_artifacts: Firewall 'Implicit Deny' rule at the bottom of the ACL
practices.implementation_tips: The last rule in your firewall must be 'Deny All'. Only open ports you explicitly need.

practices.description: Prevent remote devices from simultaneously establishing non-remote connections with organizational systems and communicating via some other connection to resources in external networks (i.e., split tunneling).
practices.implementation_tips: Disable Split Tunneling. All traffic from the remote laptop should go through the corporate firewall.

practices.description: Implement cryptographic mechanisms to prevent unauthorized disclosure of CUI during transmission unless otherwise protected by alternative physical safeguards.
practices.implementation_tips: Don't send CUI via regular email. Use an encrypted portal or S/MIME.

practices.description: Terminate network connections associated with communications sessions at the end of the sessions or after a defined period of inactivity.
practices.implementation_tips: Ensure idle sessions die after a set time (e.g., 30 mins) to prevent hijacking.

practices.description: Establish and manage cryptographic keys for cryptography employed in organizational systems.
practices.implementation_tips: Rotate your SSH keys and SSL certificates regularly. Automate with ACME/Let's Encrypt where allowed.

practices.description: Employ FIPS-validated cryptography when used to protect the confidentiality of CUI.
practices.implementation_tips: This is tough. Windows has a 'FIPS Mode' GPO, but it breaks things. Ensure your VPN and Encryption software use FIPS 140-2 validated modules.

practices.description: Prohibit remote activation of collaborative computing devices and provide indication of devices in use to users present at the device.
evidence_artifacts: Webcam/Mic settings (disabled by default if possible)
practices.implementation_tips: Ensure the 'recording light' on webcams works. Encourage physical lens covers.

practices.description: Control and monitor the use of mobile code.
evidence_artifacts: Browser GPO settings (Java, ActiveX, Flash disabled)
Proxy logs blocking specific file types
practices.implementation_tips: Disable Flash and ActiveX. Restrict Java in the browser.

practices.description: Control and monitor the use of Voice over Internet Protocol (VoIP) technologies.
practices.implementation_tips: Put phones on their own VLAN. Don't let phones talk to the server network.

practices.description: Protect the authenticity of communications sessions.
practices.implementation_tips: Use TLS for web sessions. Ensure SSH warns if the host key changes.

practices.description: Protect the confidentiality of CUI at rest.
practices.implementation_tips: Encrypt the hard drives of laptops, servers, and SANs.

practices.description: Identify, report, and correct system flaws in a timely manner.
practices.implementation_tips: Automate patching (WSUS, SCCM, Automox). Set deadlines (e.g., 7 days for Critical).

practices.description: Provide protection from malicious code at designated locations within organizational systems.
practices.implementation_tips: Install AV/EDR on everything (Windows, Linux, Mac). Ensure it updates hourly.

practices.description: Monitor system security alerts and advisories and take action in response.
practices.implementation_tips: Sign up for CISA mailing lists. When a big vulnerability hits (e.g., Log4j), start a ticket to investigate.

practices.description: Update malicious code protection mechanisms when new releases are available.
practices.implementation_tips: Set AV to auto-update definitions. Don't rely on manual updates.

practices.description: Perform periodic scans of organizational systems and real-time scans of files from external sources as files are downloaded, opened, or executed.
practices.implementation_tips: Real-time scanning is mandatory. Scheduled full scans catch things that were dormant.

practices.description: Monitor organizational systems, including inbound and outbound communications traffic, to detect attacks and indicators of potential attacks.
practices.implementation_tips: You need an IDS/IPS (Intrusion Detection System). Most firewalls have this featureturn it on.

practices.description: Identify unauthorized use of organizational systems.
practices.implementation_tips: Know what 'normal' looks like so you can spot 'abnormal'.
